alert.note: Alert for Oconee (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 27 at 10:22PM EST until February 02 at 4:45AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 130 AM EST SUNDAY... * WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Portions of northeast Georgia, including the following counties, Habersham, Rabun and Stephens and upstate South Carolina, including the following county, Oconee. * WHEN...Until 130 AM EST. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. River or stream flows are elevated. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1018 PM EST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain has fallen over the past couple hours and this area received a good amount of rain from previous storms earlier this evening. Local streams will rise to bankfull and minor flood is possible as heavy rain continues to train over the area. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Toccoa, Walhalla, Clarkesville, Tallulah Falls, Salem, Tallulah Gorge State Park, Oconee State Park, Lake Keowee, Lake Hartwell, Long Creek, Mountain Rest, Pine Mountain, Turnerville, Hollywood and Boydville. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding or landslides threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
